channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Financial markets have flashed an ominous message this month about President Trump’s ambitious and improvisational bid to reshape global trade: Be careful what you wish for
item.description: Rising volatility and dollar weakness raise fears of a financial realignment, away from U.S. shores
item.dc:creator: Chelsey Dulaney

item.title: President Trump’s federal government shake-up is taking a toll on Washington, D.C.’s economy
item.description: The president ‘s federal government shake-up is taking a toll on the U.S. capital’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: President Trump dialed back his trade war—but not on tomatoes. New fees will hit fresh tomatoes imported from Mexico in July unless a new agreement is reached.
item.description: New fees will hit fresh tomatoes imported from Mexico starting in July unless a new bilateral agreement is reached.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Peterson

item.title: Trump wants to upend the Fed. Here’s how the central bank works.
item.description: The Federal Reserve is complicated and carries out numerous functions.
item.dc:creator: Adrienne Tong

item.title: Chinese Premier Urges Officials to Think Outside the Box as Tariffs Bite
item.description: Chinese Premier Li Qiang encouraged officials to “dare to break norms,” saying the government should act swiftly to shore up market expectations, the state-run Xinhua News Agency reported.

item.title: Week Ahead for FX, Bonds: Purchasing Managers’ Surveys in Focus
item.description: Provisional U.S. purchasing managers’ surveys for April will be closely watched for signs of how businesses are reacting to tariff announcements. Equivalent surveys will also be released in the eurozone and the U.K.
item.dc:creator: Jihye Lee

item.title: As countries negotiate with President Trump, they will have to decide whether to stick with that approach or try using retaliation as leverage
item.description: As countries negotiate with the Trump administration, they will have to decide whether to stick with that approach or try using retaliation as leverage.
item.dc:creator: Bertrand Benoit

item.title: President Trump is threatening to fire Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell unless he cuts interest rates to cushion the economic blow from tariffs. The tension has put the two on a collision course.
item.description: The president wants an interest-rate cut, but his trade war has the Fed chair boxed in.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: As the U.S. has stepped up chip-export restrictions, Nvidia has maintained a China presence by making versions of its powerful processors that qualify for sale there
item.description: As the U.S. has stepped up chip-export restrictions, Nvidia has maintained a China presence by making versions of its powerful processors that qualify for sale there.
item.dc:creator: Bradley Olson

item.title: Many U.S. trading partners have a clear plan to convince Washington not to reimpose stiff tariffs on their exports: buy more American stuff
item.description: Countries are offering to buy more American goods in a bid to eliminate their trade deficits with the U.S., but not everyone is splurging.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Dubé

item.title: Trump lashed out at Fed Chair Jerome Powell in a post on social media that hinted at potentially dismissing the central bank leader. “Powell’s termination cannot come fast enough!”
item.description: The central bank leader had warned Wednesday that the Fed could face a difficult trade-off as tariffs raise prices and weaken the economy.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: President Trump has privately discussed firing Fed Chair Jerome Powell for months, including in meetings with potential replacement Kevin Warsh
item.description: The president has spoken with Kevin Warsh, a former Fed governor, about potentially sacking Powell before his term ends, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Housing starts, a measure of home construction, dropped 11.4% in March from February, marking the steepest plunge in a year
item.description: Economic uncertainty and rising material costs from tariffs darken the outlook for newly built homes.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Respondents in a recent Pew survey see trade as unbalanced in China’s favor, but are divided over the merit of increasing levies
item.description: Respondents in a recent Pew survey see trade as unbalanced, but are divided over the merit of increasing levies.
item.dc:creator: James T. Areddy

item.title: The ECB cut rates by a quarter of a percentage point to cushion Europe’s flagging economy from Trump’s trade war
item.description: The central bank cut by a quarter of a percentage point to cushion Europe’s flagging economy from Trump’s trade war.
item.dc:creator: Chelsey Dulaney

item.title: New U.S. chip-export limits that rocked global markets are the clearest sign yet from the Trump White House that whatever advances China makes in AI will have to happen without America’s help
item.description: New chip restrictions for Nvidia and AMD show the Trump administration’s determination to battle China on tech advances as well as trade.
item.dc:creator: Amrith Ramkumar

item.title: Global Growth to Slow Amid Trade War, But Recession Unlikely, IMF Head Says
item.description: Kristalina Georgieva said a breakdown of trust sparked a ‘reboot of the global trading system’ but the global economy will avoid a recession.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Turkish Central Bank Hikes Rates as Political Crackdown Threatens to Thwart Price Efforts
item.description: Turkey’s central bank raised its key interest rate, reversing a previous course of reductions as political conflict threatens to stymie the bank’s efforts to tame high inflation.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The overbuilding of apartments suddenly looks like a lucky break for the multifamily industry—thanks to tariffs
item.description: The multifamily industry built more than one million new units, but now it can pause most construction ahead of potential tariffs on building materials.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Canadian Property Market Hurt by Tariff Concerns
item.description: The nascent recovery in Canada’s housing market has become a casualty of the trade dispute with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: A WSJ podcast series explores the current state of the housing market and the factors influencing the spring home buying season—and beyond
item.description: A podcast series that explores the current state of the housing market that has left many would-be buyers on the sidelines and the factors influencing the spring home buying season—and beyond.

item.title: Young women are cutting back on little luxuries like manicures and takeout, showing America’s biggest consumer spenders are worried about the economy.
item.description: America’s biggest consumer spenders are skipping manicures and Ubers, as worries about the economy increase.
item.dc:creator: Ann-Marie Alcántara

item.title: The tariff and trade-war turmoil has rattled the market’s biggest individual investors: wealthy Americans
item.description: President Trump’s tariff moves are casting new doubts over historically popular U.S. investments.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Chung

item.title: Mortgage rates remained essentially flat during the past tumultuous week for financial markets, dealing another blow to the housing market in the crucial spring selling season
item.description: Home mortgage rates remained essentially flat during the past tumultuous week for financial markets, dealing another blow to the housing market.
item.dc:creator: Gina Heeb

item.title: Americans are loading up on vinegar, tires and furniture amid on-again, off-again tariffs
item.description: Consumers are loading up on vinegar, tires and furniture amid on-again, off-again tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: Egg Prices Creep to New Record — But There Are Signs of Relief
item.description: The average price of a dozen eggs more than doubled in March from the year before, Thursday’s Consumer Price Index release showed, climbing above $6 for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Owen Tucker-Smith

item.title: ECB Should Cut Key Rate as Euro Stages Surprise Rally, Villeroy Says
item.description: Economists said the additional tariffs of 20% on imports from the EU were likely to weaken growth in the eurozone as exports cool.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Bank of England Warns of Tariffs Threat to Stability of Global Financial System
item.description: The BOE said that further sharp falls in asset prices are likely.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: The Trump administration is targeting value-added taxes, saying they discriminate against U.S. exporters. Other countries aren’t ready to give them up.
item.description: Value-added taxes, which the president says discriminate against U.S. exporters, fund a large share of government budgets in many countries.
item.dc:creator: Bertrand Benoit

item.title: Since President Trump announced sweeping tariffs on imported goods Wednesday, Americans have been busy “adding to cart”
item.description: President Trump’s new tariffs are spurring some shoppers to stock up. “Now is the time to buy.”
item.dc:creator: Xavier Martinez

item.title: Shot by Both Sides, the Eurozone Faces Recession Threat
item.description: With the Trump administration targeting its exports, Europe may deal with an economic contraction and the direct impact of lower exports will drag growth down and deliver a shock to confidence.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Initial U.S. Jobless Claims Fell Last Week
item.description: The week through March 29 brought 219,000 initial jobless claims, compared with 225,000 a week earlier and economists expectations of 228,000 claims.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: U.S. Hiring, Quits and Layoffs Were Steady in February
item.description: A Labor Department survey revealed that 3.2 million people quit their jobs, a 2% rate that has fallen over the past 12 months.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Americans are in the dumps about the economy. The big question: What will that pessimism mean for the economy?
item.description: When consumers and businesses are feeling down, the effects can ripple through the economy—sometimes.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: State officials are eager to snap up cybersecurity workers sent packing in a wave of federal layoffs by Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency, posting splashy recruiting ads and offering fast-track promotions and other benefits.
item.description: The Trump administration’s job cuts offer state tech recruiters a chance to build cyber teams in a tight labor market. “It’s a full-court press,” said Colin Ahern, New York state’s chief cyber officer.
item.dc:creator: Angus Loten

item.title: Trump Contract Cuts Come for Smaller Consultants
item.description: The Trump administration’s cost-cutting efforts have put a target on the backs of the biggest government contractors. But their smaller competitors are reeling as well.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: The U.S. continued to generate jobs at a brisk pace in February, offering reassurances that the labor market has remained strong since President Trump took office
item.description: The U.S. continued to generate jobs at a steady pace in February, offering reassurances that the labor market has remained relatively stable since President Trump took office.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart
